appendix.title: The HLA region
appendix.para: Here we give a summary of the HLA (human leukocyte antigen) system in humans, the major histocompatiblity complex (MHC) in humans. The HLA classical class I and II genes are a set of closely linked, highly polymorphic genes involved in the immune response. The HLA genes also influence susceptibility to over 200 diseases, including autoimmune diseases, cancers, and infectious diseases. A number of functional and population features implicate selection as an important factor maintaining the extensive HLA variation. Although the precise nature of this selection is not known, response to a wide variety of pathogens is believed to be a major evolutionary pressure. Recent advances in genomics, combined with increasing knowledge of structure-function of HLA molecules, provides new tools for exploring HLA polymorphism and an opportunity to address fundamental questions about HLA sequence variation, immunity, and disease. Such detailed information has not previously been available and is critical for a complete understanding of the immune system, autoimmune and infectious diseases, transplantation, and development of T-cell therapies and vaccines.

sect1.title: Map of region
sect1.para: The HLA region maps to ch. 6p21.31. It consists of 3.6 Mb of DNA and contains 224 identified genes, 128 of which are predicted to be expressed, arranged in three major gene clusters (The MHC Sequencing Consortium 1999, Rhodes and Trowsdale 1999). Only some of the HLA region genes are involved in the immune response. Much of our interest is in the HLA classical class I (A, B, and C) (1.8 Mb) and class II (DR, DQ, and DP) (1.2 Mb) genes, which flank the class III region (see ).

sect1.para: The six classical class I and II loci are highly polymorphic and encode structurally homologous products which are expressed on the surface of antigen presenting cells. HLA molecules are receptors which capture peptide fragments of antigen that help T cells recognize and respond to foreign antigens. The division into class I and II molecules is based on their structure, tissue distribution, source of peptide antigen, and the function of responding T cells (McCluskey and Peh 1999, Little and Parham 1999). Each of the class II DR, DQ, and DP regions contains at least two genes, denoted A and B respectively, e.g., DRA1, DRB1. The class III region includes immune system and non-immune system loci encoding, e.g., complement proteins, Factor B, C2, C4, and tumor necrosis factors, TNFA and B.

The recombination distance between the most distant of the HLA classical loci, the class I A locus and the class II DPB1 locus is 3.7 cM (Carrington 1999). The HLA region in fact extends beyond these boundaries; e.g., the non-classical class I gene involved in hemochromatosis, HFE, maps 4 Mb from HLA-A (Rhodes and Trowsdale 1999, http://www.sanger.ac.uk/).

sect1.title: Structure and function of class I and class II molecules
sect1.para: The processed self and foreign peptide fragments presented by the classical HLA molecules (see ) usually consist of 8–10 amino acids (class I) or 12–20 amino acids (class II), and are of either intracellular or extracellular origin respectively. Class I and II genes are distantly related at the sequence level, but the protein structures are quite similar, and both are members of the immunoglobulin superfamily. The classical class I molecules (A, B, and C) are comprised of a heavy chain, encoded by the HLA region, and a light chain, encoded by the invariant 2-microglobulin gene on ch. 15 (). The extracellular portion of the heavy chain is divided into 3 domains: 1, 2, and 3, each about 90 amino acids long. The 1 and 2 domains form a groove bordered by two -helices with a -pleated sheet floor. It is in this groove, referred to as the antigen recognition site (ARS), that the peptide fragment is bound. The classical class II molecules (DR, DQ, and DP) are composed of an  and a  chain (from the A and B genes respectively) in a non-covalent association (). The extracellular portion of each chain consists of two domains (1, 2 and 1, 2), each about 90 amino acids long. The ARS is formed by the 1 and 1 domains.

figure.title: Class I and class II structure and antigen presentation

sect1.para: An MHC molecule binds only to peptides conforming to certain structural requirements. A particular MHC allele is thus only able to present a subset of the available peptides to T cells. Peptide motifs important for binding to HLA molecules, including critical residues, e.g., position 57 of DQB1, have been defined by sequence analysis of naturally processed peptides, analysis with synthetic peptides, and predictive inference of binding preference based on similarity of peptide-binding environments. While some of the most highly polymorphic HLA amino acid residues line the groove of the ARS, conferring unique peptide- and TCR-binding properties on each MHC molecule, clusters of highly conserved amino acid residues are found outside the groove and at both ends of the ARS.

Class I molecules are expressed on most cells and interact with CD8+ (cytotoxic) T cells, playing a critical part in tissue graft rejection as well as in the immune response to viruses and intracellular pathogens, and cancerous cells. Class II molecules are expressed only on a restricted subset of immune system cells, e.g., macrophages and B-cells, and interact with CD4+ (helper) T cells, exerting an immune system response through the production of various lymphokines, such as IL-2, affecting, among other things, B cell differentiation and antibody production.

During the maturation of the immune system, T-cell clones are deleted or rendered anergic to self peptides in the context of HLA presentation. Autoimmune disease is thought to result when there is a breakdown in self-tolerance. Molecular mechanisms have been proposed for the direct role of HLA molecules in the cascade of autoimmune events leading to type 1 diabetes (previously referred to as insulin dependent diabetes mellitus—IDDM) and other autoimmune diseases.

sect1.title: HLA polymorphism
sect1.para: The polymorphism of many of the HLA genes and MHC genes in other species, is extraordinary (); e.g., 320 alleles are currently described for the class II DRB1 gene, and 399 for the class I B gene, with much of the variation present at the protein level. The genetic variation is concentrated in the amino acid residues of the ARS (see e.g., Little and Parham 1999). Alleles at HLA-A, for example, differ from each other by up to 20–30 amino acids. In contrast to these highly polymorphic loci, there are also HLA region loci which show very little polymorphism, e.g., the non-classical class I genes, some class II genes such as DRA1, and the complement class III genes.

Point mutations generating new variation and genetic exchange (recombination or gene conversion) reassorting extant polymorphism into new combinations have played key roles in creating HLA diversity (Little and Parham 1999). For class I genes, generation of variants at the B locus appears to be more rapid than at the A or C loci. HLA variation shows population structure; some alleles differ in frequency between ethnic groups, others are unique to a specific ethnic or geographic group, particularly those of the highly polymorphic class I B and class II DRB1 genes (see e.g., Imanishi et al. 1992, Charron 1997).

To explain the extensive polymorphism at the HLA loci, Klein (1987) proposed a “trans-species” hypothesis whereby ancestral allelic polymorphism is maintained, presumably by balancing selection, after species divergence. First applied to rodent species, this theory is also supported by evidence in primates where, for example, certain chimpanzee alleles are more closely related to specific human alleles than they are to other chimpanzee alleles. This segregation of alleles across species into “allelic lineages” is based primarily on sequence homology and serological specificities, although these groupings for the class I HLA-A locus have also been correlated with functional attributes such as peptide binding specificities (Jakobsen et al. 1998). For class I, allelic lineages are seen most clearly at the less polymorphic loci A and C, however at even the most polymorphic class II locus, DRB1, the alleles can be divided into 13 distinct allelic lineages which are highly correlated with the serological DR specificities. Phylogenetic studies support the idea that many of these lineages are very old, but that alleles within each lineage have been generated recently in hominoid evolution (Bergstrom et al. 1998).

Molecular typing methods, for example using PCR (polymerase chain reaction) and SSOP (sequence-specific-oligonucleotide probes), are now the standard for typing class II loci (see e.g., Middleton 1999). The greater degree and type of variability of HLA class I compared to class II loci has made molecular typing more difficult than initially expected by researchers in the field. Recently, molecular typing methods have also been applied to class I loci (see e.g., Cao et al. 1999). For molecularly defined alleles, the first two numbers of the allele designation refer to the serological type of the allele, so that DRB1*0401 and 0402 are subtypes of DR4. This is indicative of the increased resolution of alleles available with molecular typing.

Microsatellites in the HLA region share the characteristics of microsatellites found elsewhere in the genome, including high density, high mutation rates, and high polymorphism. The utility of microsatellites for the identification of HLA region disease genes has been demonstrated (see e.g., Foissac et al. 1997 for review, Carrington et al. 1999). Identification of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) across the HLA region in diverse ethnic groups is in progress (Geraghty et al. 1999).

sect1.title: Selection in the HLA region
sect1.para: Allele frequencies within a population for serologically typed HLA class I A, B, and C and the class II DR locus, and for molecularly typed class II DRB1, DQA1, and DQB1, are often more even than expected under neutrality, suggesting that some form of balancing selection is operating on these genes (see e.g., Hedrick and Thomson 1983, Salamon et al. 1999, Valdes et al. 1999). In contrast, the distribution of DPB1 alleles rarely differs significantly from neutrality expectations; usually there is a fairly common allele, which may differ between populations.

From the examination of class I and II genes across species, nonsynonymous amino acid substitutions per site (dn) are proportionally more common than synonymous substitutions (ds) in the ARS, indicative of balancing selection maintaining the extensive variation (Hughes and Nei 1988, 1989). Regions not involved in peptide binding typically show dn < ds, the pattern expected under purifying selection.

The specific mechanism of the selection acting on MHC variation has not yet been identified, although models invoking heterozygote advantage are strong candidates, since individuals heterozygous for HLA present a wider range of foreign peptides to T cells (Parham and Ohta 1996, Edwards and Hedrick 1998). Observations on the pathogens Plasmodium falciparum (malaria), human and simian immunodeficiency viruses (HIV and SIV), Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), and hepatitis B have indicated that HLA restricted cytotoxic T-cell responses may influence the evolution of the host-pathogen relationship. HLA associations with infectious diseases may differ between geographic regions and reflect pathogen variation. This may account for some of the differences seen in HLA allele frequencies between geographical areas.

Other mechanisms proposed to explain MHC variability are disassortative mating and maternal-fetal incompatibility. There is evidence of maternal-fetal incompatibility in humans, and disassortative mating for MHC in mice (Penn and Potts 1998) and in humans (Ober et al. 1997, Gnin et al. 2000), although it is not seen in all studies (Hedrick and Black 1997). Multiple mechanisms are probably responsible for HLA diversity (Edwards and Hedrick 1998, Meyer and Thomson 2001).

sect1.title: HLA linkage disequilibrium
sect1.para: Significant linkage disequilibrium (LD) between alleles at different loci is observed across the HLA region (see e.g., Imanishi et al. 1992, Charron 1997). Disequilibrium is in many cases nearly complete between the tightly linked class II DRB1, DQA1, and DQB1 loci. For example, almost all DR3 haplotypes in many ethnic groups are DRB1*0301-DQA1*0501-DQB1*0201. The class I B and C loci also exhibit very high LD, while less closely linked loci show medium levels of LD (e.g., class I A and B). The observed levels of overall LD for HLA data are incompatible with neutrality expectations.

Huttley et al. (1999) used data from many laboratories on ~5000 microsatellites from the Utah and Amish CEPH families to examine LD levels across the genome of 54 independent chromosomes. They identified ten regions that showed higher LD than the HLA region and concluded that the pattern of LD was consistent with the action of natural selection on loci in these regions.

sect1.title: HLA associated diseases
sect1.para: Genes in the HLA region are known to influence susceptibility to many diseases. These include complex autoimmune diseases such as type 1 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis (RA), and multiple sclerosis (MS); Hodgkin disease and other cancers; infectious diseases including malaria, tuberculosis, and AIDS, and diseases of unknown etiology such as narcolepsy (Tiwari and Terasaki 1985, Thorsby 1997). In some cases the HLA classical class I and II genes have been implicated as directly involved in disease, e.g., ankylosing spondylitis (class I), type 1 diabetes, RA, MS, celiac disease, and narcolepsy (class II). In other cases, the association with classical HLA genes was due to LD, as with hemochromatosis. The HLA associated diseases are in general genetically complex. They can involve multiple HLA and non-HLA loci and exhibit incomplete penetrance, genetic heterogeneity within the HLA region, and synergistic effects. Type 1 diabetes exhibits all of these features (Thomson 1997, 2001a,). The class II genes DRB1, DQA1, and DQB1 all contribute to type 1 diabetes. Genetic variation additional to DR-DQ is also required to explain all of the HLA region contribution to disease.

sect2.title: Introduction
sect2.para: Mendelian genetics was rediscovered in the early 1900's. The Hardy-Weinberg law is the foundation of population genetics, and was derived independently in 1908 by an English mathematician Hardy and a German physician Weinberg. R.C. Punnett brought to the attention of Hardy a remark of Yule (a geneticist)—Mr. Yule is reported to have suggested as a criticism of the Mendelian position that if brachydactyly (short fingeredness) is dominant “in the course of time one would expect, in the absence of counteracting factors, to get 3 brachydactylous individuals to 1 normal.” Of course we now understand that Yule is confusing the Mendelian 3:1 ratio in an F1 cross (Aa x Aa gives 3A-:1aa) with population features.

Basically we want to consider whether or not Mendelian segregation causes changes in the genetic structure of a population. We want to consider the effect of this factor acting in isolation from all other possible factors, so we assume:

listitem.para: mutation and migration rates are negligible (no mutation, no migration)

infinite population size, i.e., the population size is so large that we can ignore small chance variations in allele frequencies, so we can predict exactly what the allele frequencies will be in a future generation, this is known as a deterministic model, e.g., the equivalent when a coin is tossed is that you would get exactly 50% heads and 50% tails, not a distribution of values as seen in reality with a finite sample size (stochastic model).

sect2.para: The importance of the Hardy-Weinberg law is that if there are no counteracting forces, then the frequencies of alleles do not change in a population. In other words, variation in a population, under a Mendelian system, tends to be maintained. We contrast this to the previously believed blending inheritance where genetic variation is decreased each generation. Further, the expected genotype frequencies each generation are determined by the allele frequencies, and are termed Hardy-Weinberg proportions (HWP). Continued random mating leads to the same genotype (and allele) frequencies, hence the term Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium.

sect2.title: Hardy-Weinberg proportions (HWP)
sect2.para: We consider initially a two allele system, but the results extend easily to multiple alleles. The two alleles are A and a with respective frequencies p and q (p+q=1, so note that we have only one independent variable). If gametes combine at random then the frequencies of the three genotypic classes in the next generation are:

(Note that the 2 for the heterozygote class comes about since there are two ways a heterozygote can form, each with probability pq, the father can supply the A allele and the mother the a allele, or vice versa.) Using gene (allele) counting, with f(.) denoting frequency, such that f(A) = f(AA) + f(Aa)/2, and assuming we can distinguish the heterozygote from the two homozygote classes, we obtain,
sect2.informalequation: f(A) = p2 + pq = p(p + q) = p.
sect2.para: Thus, we have demonstrated that under the assumptions of the Hardy-Weinberg law, the allele frequencies in the offspring generation are the same as those in the parental generation. This results from the fact that there are no forces operating to cause systematic change in allele frequencies, since the two alleles in this case are considered to be selectively equivalent (neutral with respect to each other). Further, it follows that in all subsequent generations, the genotypic distribution will remain p2AA, 2pqAa, q2aa. With overlapping generations, there is rapid convergence to the HWP. For a multi-allelic system, the results are exactly equivalent, with the expected homozygote genotype frequencies given by pi2, where pi is the allele frequency for the ith allele, and the expected heterozygote genotype frequencies are given by 2pipj, with i<j. Although complicated in words, the Hardy Weinberg law is , statistically speaking, a simple statement about independence of allele frequencies at a locus.
For example, we consider the ABO blood group system: A is dominant to O, B is dominant to O, A and B are co-dominant. For the following allele frequencies, A = 0.30, B = 0.10, O = 0.60, the HWP are:

(Note in this case that the allele frequencies cannot be estimated by gene (allele) counting, since allele O is recessive. The allele frequencies in this case are estimated by an iterative procedure.)

Due to the finite size of samples, observed genotype frequencies are not expected to be in exact HWP. Two illustrative examples using the codominant MN blood group system are shown below, which have the same allele frequencies f(M) = 0.6, f(N) = 0.4, and hence the same HWP, but very different observed genotype frequencies (the first very close to HWP, the second very different from HWP):

The strength of the Hardy-Weinberg law is that much of the variation in natural populations follows HWP; its weakness is that selection, etc., have to be very strong to detect deviations from HWP.

sect2.title: Testing fit to HWP
sect2.para: There are two important issues with regard to HWP testing. First is testing the overall fit of a sample. Traditionally, a large sample goodness-of-fit chi-square is performed when the number of genotypes is small relative to the sample size. With the development of modern molecular technology, the situation is often different from this. For instance, over 400 alleles have been described at the HLA class I B locus, although not all these alleles are seen in any one population. However, it is not uncommon for researchers to distinguish more than a few dozen alleles in a reasonable-sized sample for the HLA class I and class II loci. Therefore, in many studies the genotypic matrix is relatively sparse and some simulation approaches, e.g. Guo and Thompson (1992), are more appropriate than their asymptotic counter parts in testing for overall fit of HWP.

The second issue is testing at the individual heterozygote level. For a given sample, beside the overall fit, researchers are often interested in knowing which individual heterozygote significantly deviates from its HW expectation, especially when the genotype matrix is relatively large. If one rejects the overall fit, which heterozygote(s) is/are responsible for the deviation? If one does not reject the overall fit, are there consistent and significant patterns of deviation at the individual level, which were not detected by an overall test? This is especially relevant when genetic data are available from more than one population. By comparing patterns across populations, consistent deviations, which may not be strong enough to be found in the overall tests of an individual sample, could be detected. This will allow researchers to generate future hypothesis on the mechanisms causing such patterns and facilitate further study of this genetic region.

sect3.title: The chi-square test
sect3.para: The basis of the chi-square test is to calculate expected genotype values based on HWP for individual genotype values and test for fit to HWP using an overall test. When expected genotype counts are >=5 calculate the individual chi-square value for this genotype, i.e., (O-E)2/E, where O is observed and E is expected for that genotype, and add together the contributions of each genotype. If there are no rare genotypes (expected <5), the degrees of freedom (d.f.) for the overall chi-square test are given by k(k-1)/2, where k is the number of alleles in the sample under study. This comes from the formula, d.f. = number of categories - 1 - number of independent parameters estimated from the data needed to determine the expected values (in this case k-1, since if we know k-1 allele frequencies we can determine the kth allele frequency). Since the number of categories (genotypes) in this case is k (homozygotes) + k(k-1)/2 (heterozygotes) = k(k+1)/2, from which we subtract 1 (since given the frequencies of all except one of these categories we can always determine the frequency of the remaining category given the sample size), and subtract (k-1) (the number of independent allele frequencies need to estimate the HWP), to give the d.f. = k(k-1)/2.

As examples we consider a 2 allele case, as above, with a range of observed (O) genotype frequencies, all with p = 0.6, q = 0.4, and all with sample size N = 100 individuals. In all cases the expected (E) HWP genotype counts are 36, 48, and 16. Next to the observed numbers in each case the (O - E) values are given. The d.f. = 1 in each case for the overall chi-square test. For a chi-square distribution with 1 d.f., the cut-off points, i.e., rejection of the null hypothesis of fit to HWP are 3.84 (5%), 6.64 (1%), and 10.83 (0.1%). If the overall chi-square value is greater than one of these values, then the null hypothesis of overall fit to HWP for these genotypes is rejected with the type 1 error (probability you have made a mistake) given in parentheses.

The individual genotype contributions (O-E)2/E can each be asymptotically tested against a chi-square distribution with 1 d.f., to determine which genotypes are contributing to significant deviation from HWP.
With a 3 allele system, there are 6 genotype classes (A1A1, A1A2, A1A3, A2A2, A2A3, A3A3) and if all have expected values >=5, the overall chi-square will have 3 d.f.

When expected genotype counts are <5 a lumped category of observed and expected values for all these genotypes needs to be formed, and test fit to null hypothesis (no deviation from HWP) of this chi-square value with 1 degree of freedom and output p value. The chi-square value from this category is added to the cumulative chi-square value from the genotypes >=5 class to give the overall chi-square value which is tested against the null hypothesis of fit to HWP, degrees of freedom equals the number of genotypes falling into >=5 class minus the number of independent parameters estimated. In the case of the highly polymorphic HLA data, with high allele numbers and many sparse cells, this calculation may result in zero or negative d.f. (for which a test of significance cannot be applied). In this case, an appropriate strategy is to just subtract the number of alleles seen in the genotypes <=5 category. If this still gives a problem, the rarer alleles need to be appropriately combined.

For the above Pearson’s goodness of fit test, the general rule of thumb about the validity of the asymptotics is that the expected cell counts need to be at least 5 (Cochran 1954), although it is found that the rule tends to be conservative (Bradley et al. 1979). Several corrections to this goodness of fit test have been proposed to improve the approximation when small sample expectations exist in the sample. Yates (1934) suggested using the continuity correction, 1/2, i.e., (absolute value (0 - E) - 1/2)2/E. Emigh (1980) showed that in some cases a correction of 1/4 performs better.

Elston and Forthofer (1977) derived the likelihood ratio statistic for HWP testing. It was based on comparison of two maximum likelihoods of a sample coming from the multinomial distribution of genotype counts with (L0) versus without (L1) the HWP constraint. When the null hypothesis is true, i.e., HWP, the test statistic, G2 (= -2ln(L0/L1)), follows a chi-square distribution, with k(k-1)/2 d.f.

Below is an example of a contingency table with genotypic observed and expected counts, illustrating the problem of sparse cells (the data is for the DPA1 locus of the HLA region, from a Filipino population). The identity of the alleles (0102, 0103…) present in each genotype are given on the margins, and genotypes with expected counts <5 are shown in bold. Notice how the expected values for individual genotypes are often very low. These inflate the chi-square values and may result in spurious rejection of the null hypothesis.
In this example sparse cells are fairly common, even though this is by no means a particularly polymorphic HLA locus. The problem is particularly serious in the cases where polymorphism is greater.

sect3.title: Exact tests
sect3.para: Levene (1949) described the conditional sampling distribution for Hardy Weinberg populations. An algorithm for generating the exact distribution of samples drawn from a population in HWP was proposed by Louis and Dempster (1987). Using this algorithm, one could develop an exact test for HWP, analogous to Fisher’s 2x2 exact test. This approach can be applied to an arbitrary number of alleles, especially when sample sizes are small. It provides a reliable alternative to the standard goodness of fit test and methods that require corrections. Below is an example of a test for deviations from HWP using such an exact test.

Consider a sample of 40 individuals, where the genotype counts for a biallelic locus are: n(AA) = 5, n(Aa) = 9, and n(aa) = 26. The total count for each allele is: n(A) = 19 , and n(a) = 61. Using the expression given by Levene (1949) we compute the probability of obtaining this set of genotypes, conditional on the observed counts of alleles, under the null hypothesis of no association (i.e. HWP). The probability of this combination is 0.0205

The challenge now is to decide whether the probability associated to this outcome is particularly low. This can be done by comparing the probability of this specific genotypic combination with that of all other possible combinations. This is summarized in the table below. All genotypic possibilities, conditional on the observed number of alleles, are listed and sorted by their probabilities.
The probability of the observed genotypes is among the 5% lowest ways to distribute genes into genotypic categories, so we reject the null hypothesis that the genotypes fit HWP.

However, with an increase in the number of alleles and sample size, the number of possible configurations of samples using the above algorithm grows exponentially. It becomes computationally cumbersome or even infeasible. To avoid complete enumeration, Guo and Thompson (1992) developed two simulation approaches to perform an approximate exact overall HWP test. In their conventional Monte Carlo approach, gametes were permuted to generate new genotypes and the Monte Carlo p value of the observed sample can be estimated by comparing Levene’s probabilities of the sample and those from different permutations.

In the Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) approach of Guo and Thompson (1992), a finite and irreducible Markov chain of states of genotype counts was generated using the Metropolis algorithm (Metropolis et al. 1953), where the transition probabilities between any two states were a function of the ratio of probabilities of being in each of them. The equilibrium distribution of the Markov chain was set to have the same allele frequencies as those in the observed sample and the HWP genotype probabilities. After a “dememorization” period, the p value was estimated by calculating the fraction of times the Markov chain was in any states which had equal or lower probability than the observed one.

In Chen and Thomson (1999) the variance for the disequilibrium coefficient in the individual Hardy-Weinberg test has been determined. An exact test using a statistic based on this variance has been developed (Chen et al. 1999).

sect2.title: Testing fit to HWP of HLA data
sect2.para: The Guo and Thompson (1992) overall test, and the Chen et al. (1999) exact test of individual heterozygote deviations from HWP, have been applied to HLA class II genotype data in 26 populations (Chen et al. 1999). Eighty of the 99 overall tests fitted HWP (73% for DRB1, 89% for DQA1, 81% for DQB1, and 81% for DPB1), deviations were both locus and group specific. The individual test results indicated that the departure was partly due to recent admixture. Evidence for selection as a cause of deviation from HWP was also observed; the fact that the DQB1 allele *0301 was involved in significant individual heterozygote deficiencies in eight samples could well implicate selection.

In many cases the genotypes showing significant deviation contain alleles suspected of being the result of admixture or recent origin within the group. It is possible that admixture has effectively caused the deviation from HWP, suggesting its very recent history to the group, perhaps within one generation. Other explanations for the deviation from HWP, including non-random mating patterns with regard to admixed individuals within the ethnic group, must also be considered. On the other hand, significant deviations from HWP are also seen in populations which showed very little evidence for any admixture, e.g., the Mixe, an amerindian group from Oaxaca, Mexico (Hollenbach et al. 2001). These deviations could be due to the impact of selection pressures from infectious diseases on these genes.

Testing for fit to HWP can also serve a useful role in assessing the initial quality of typing results. Should deviations from expectations occur, it is possible to look again at the raw data and the methods employed to generate them, and if deemed necessary repeat typing and use alternative methods to confirm results. This may be particularly relevant for HLA typing in non-Caucasian populations, where new alleles which may not be detected by the typing system are more likely to occur.

Also, we have to caution here that the individual heterozygote testing approach is most useful if one has an a priori hypothesis about one or a few heterozygotes in the sample, regarding their excess or deficit from HWP. By applying the method to all heterozygotes, we face the problem of multiple tests, and some results merely reflecting type 1 error. Therefore any p values need to judged with care. However, the approach is still of general interest and validity in detecting patterns and generating future hypotheses.

sect1.title: Measuring non-randomness of alleles on chromosomes
sect1.para: The description of genetic variation at the population level usually begins with consideration of allelic variation at a single gene locus, as discussed above. The next step is to consider genetic variation at two or more loci simultaneously, including non-random associations. Gametic disequilibrium (usually referred to as linkage disequilibrium LD) describes the non-random association of alleles at different genetic loci. While linkage disequilibrium can be more generally referred to as “gametic phase disequilibrium”, or, in other words, the non-random occurrence in gametes of alleles at two or more loci. In general it is immaterial whether the two loci are linked. In practice, and in almost all of the literature today, it is used only for linked loci. Thus, it can also be defined as the non-random occurrence on chromosomes in the population of alleles at two or more loci.

sect2.title: Tests for Linkage Disequilibrium and its statistical significance
sect2.para: One can estimate the frequencies of haplotypes in a population and can measure the amount of non-randomness. It is important to distinguish the existence of non-randomness from specific statistics used to measure that non-randomness. There are several different statistics in use today and considerable debate about which is “correct”. The classic pairwise gametic disequilibrium parameter, usually denoted D, is given by the difference between the observed frequency of a gametic type and the frequency expected on the basis of random association of alleles in gametes. Consider two genes (denoted A and B), with two alleles each (A, a and B, b), and four gametic types (also referred to as haplotypes): AB, Ab, aB, and ab. The frequencies of the four gametes (denoted f(AB) etc.) can be described in terms of the allele frequencies pA (pa= 1 - pA) and pB (pb = 1 - pB) at the two loci, and the gametic disequilibrium parameter D, as follows:
f (AB) = pA pB + D,
f (Ab) = pA pb - D,
f (aB) = pa pB - D,
f (ab) = pa pb + D,

where D = f(AB) - pA pB = f(AB) f(ab) - f(Ab) f(aB). D can be either positive or negative, depending on which specific alleles are referenced. If D = 0 (a state referred to as gametic or linkage equilibrium) then the alleles at the two loci are randomly associated. If D > 0 the allele A occurs more often with allele B than expected by chance (and hence a with b), while if D < 0 alleles A and b (and hence a and B) are preferentially associated. The possible value of D in a two-locus system is constrained by the fact that the frequency of any haplotype is constrained as 0 ≤ pAB ≤ min(pA , pB) and thus the disequilibrium coefficient is constrained by

-papb, -pApB ≤ pAB ≤ pApb, papB. Consequently, interpretation of D values is dependent on the allele frequencies. To avoid this, the normalized gametic disequilibrium D' = D/Dmax is often considered, where Dmax is equal to either the lesser of pA pb or pa pB if D is positive, and the lesser of pA pB or pa pb if D is negative (Lewontin, 1964). The advantage of this measure over D is that it has a range from -1 to +1, regardless of the allele frequencies. Unfortunately, for both D and D' the values are not related to statistical significance and are dependent on allele frequencies. Therefore, several other measures are being used: δ, Δ = r, r2, d2. These are reviewed by Devlin and Risch (1995) except for d2, used by Kruglyak (1999), which is closely related to D2 and to r2: d2 = D2 / [f(1-f)]2 and d2 = r2 m(1-m) / [f(1-f)]2 , where f is the variant frequency and m is the marker allele frequency. Note, this is referenced to the locus of the "variant". The correlation coefficient, r = D / (pA pa pB pb)_, with a range from -1 to +1, is often used, as well as r2 with a range from 0 to +1. An example from the HLA region is the association between alleles at the A, B and DR loci. The combinations A1-B8 and B8-DR3 have fairly high normalized disequilibrium values (D’ = 0.65 and D’ = 0.73, respectively).

There is a relationship between D and the recombination fraction c between two loci. (Various symbols are used for the recombination fraction; the most common symbol in human genetics is θ.) In the absence of drift and selection, changes in gamete frequencies over generations only occur by recombination in individuals heterozygous at both loci under consideration. In fact, the value of D decreases by a fraction (1-c) each generation under random mating and a neutral model. Thus the LD in this case converges to zero (random association of alleles) with time as (1 - c)n, where n is the number of generations. The more loosely linked are two loci, the faster the decay of gametic disequilibrium. On the other hand, for very tightly linked loci gametic disequilibrium may exist for a very long time.

It is possible, although relatively rare, that unlinked loci can be in significant LD, and that very closely linked loci may be in linkage (gametic) equilibrium. The value of LD is often expected to change each generation. Further, a population at genetic equilibrium can have significant LD (e.g., under various selection schemes). The term linkage disequilibrium is thus an unfortunate choice and the term gametic disequilibrium is preferable, although also not perfect. However, the term linkage disequilibrium is commonly used and simply abbreviated LD. There are two important points to remember: (1) that tight linkage or molecular proximity does not automatically mean there will be LD and (2) that unlinked loci can show LD for a variety of reasons.

Linkage disequilibrium can occur in populations as a consequence of a number of factors (see Hedrick 1983 for review): (1) mutation–when a new mutant arises, it occurs in one individual and is in linkage disequilibrium with all polymorphic loci in the population; (2) selection–either acting directly on the two loci, or transient linkage disequilibrium can also be created with neutral loci via a hitchhiking event with a selected locus (Thomson 1977); (3) migration or admixture–generation of linkage disequilibrium by these forces requires that the allelic frequencies of both loci in the two populations be different, and this difference must be substantial to generate very much linkage disequilibrium; and (4) random genetic drift–while the expected value of pairwise linkage disequilibrium due to drift over many generations is zero, the variance is large for closely linked loci in small populations.

The amount of linkage disequilibrium observed in a population is also affected by a number of factors: (1) recombination–significant linkage disequilibrium may be maintained for a long time between very closely linked loci; (2) selection–if the selection is sufficiently strong compared to the recombination rate linkage disequilibrium can be maintained at an equilibrium state, and will occur transiently with a hitchhiking event; (3) non-random mating–high levels of inbreeding and self-fertilization in plants can retard the rate of approach to linkage equilibrium; and (4) population demographics–a small founder population or a bottleneck in the recent past can cause significant linkage disequilibrium due to genetic drift for closely linked loci, and while less linkage disequilibrium will be generated by genetic drift in a rapidly growing population (Slatkin 1994), any linkage disequilibrium present before or during the early phase of the expansion will persist.

As seen in Section II, the pattern of LD at many loci argues that human populations in sub-Saharan Africa have little LD beyond a few kb while all non-African populations tend to have much more LD and to share the same haplotypes. Thus the evidence argues that most LD in non-African populations was produced by a founder effect (a very large amount of random genetic drift caused by a quite small population size) associated with the expansion of modern humans out of Africa.

The definition of LD is "easily" extended to accommodate more than two alleles at a locus or more than two loci: non-randomness on chromosomes in the population across however many loci and/or among however many alleles. However, statistics to quantify LD become more problematic in such cases. All of the above are defined for a pair of specified alleles at a pair of loci. For multiallelic loci, one must choose one allele at each locus and then pool all other alleles. This gives n1 x n2 different pairwise measures for two loci with n1 and n2 alleles, respectively. Interpreting such a set of LD statistics is not simple or obvious. When considering three or more loci, higher order disequilibrium terms are also needed (see Robinson et al. 1991a). For example, in a three-locus system a gametic frequency can be expressed in terms of the three-allele frequencies, the three pairwise gametic disequilibria, and a single measure of third order gametic disequilibrium. However, when multi-allelic loci are included or multiple (>3) sites are included, the pairwise values and the higher order disequilibrium terms become difficult to interpret. Many papers now present data for multiple sites in a haplotype as all possible pairwise comparisons.

To date only one measure attempts to measure non-randomness in a general manner for an arbitrary number of sites with an arbitrary number of alleles at each: the permutation test based ξ (Zhao et al., 1999). While that measure has not been generally used by researchers studying LD in humans, it illustrates the distinction between the pairwise measures and the general concept of non-randomness of alleles on chromosomes in a population.

General population level observations are that there is an overall proportionality between linkage disequilibrium and the inverse of the recombination distance (Huttley et al. 1999). This rule however breaks down in very closely linked regions (Reich et al. 2001, Huttley et al. 1999, Jorde et al. 1994, Klitz et al. 1995). Selection is expected to produce linkage disequilibrium non-randomly across the genome, whereas all the other factors should act randomly over the genome. In study of the CEPH families, linkage disequilibrium was found to be non-randomly distributed throughout the genome (Huttley et al. 1999). Some regions, such as HLA, showed strong evidence of selection and significant linkage disequilibrium which spanned 3 cM or more, and an additional 10 genetic regions showed linkage disequilibrium equal to or greater than in the HLA region. Most recently, a series of papers in the October 2001 Nature Genetics present evidence that LD in humans exists in blocks of strong LD separated by short intervals across which all LD breaks down. Recombination hot spots and cold spots is one possible explanation for such a pattern. How general around the genome this pattern is remains to be seen.

Population and evolutionary aspects of a genetic region are highly relevant to the study of Mendelian and complex diseases. These relate to our ability to localize and identify disease predisposing variants, and to our understanding of the mechanisms by which some disease predisposing genes can become relatively common in a population.

sect2.title: Haplotype estimation on population and patient data sets
sect2.para: The accuracy of haplotype estimates is of increasing interest with regard to population data and disease association studies, for microsatellite, SNP, and protein level variation. Marker-disease associations that are not detected at the single locus level, may nevertheless be detected in a multi-locus analysis. This was the initial observation in the study of ch. 19q13.2 APOE region variation and multiple sclerosis (Barcellos 1996, and 1997c), and in analysis of ch. 19 markers and alcohol dependence (Valdes et al. 1999).

Procedures that make use of the expectation-maximization (EM) algorithm to estimate haplotype frequencies (HFs) from unphased genotype data are in common use in genetic studies, e.g., HAUPT (Baur and Danilovs 1980), Arlequin (Schneider et al. 2000), HAPLO (Hawley and Kidd 1995), and 3LOCUS.PAS (Long et al. 1995). The EM algorithm uses these unphased genotype frequencies along with the assumption of Hardy-Weinberg proportions (HWP) to converge on HF estimates. The EM algorithm is an iterative algorithm for computing maximum likelihood estimates (MLEs) in an incomplete-data setting (Dempster et al. 1977, Lange 1997). The algorithm is straightforward. Each iteration consists of two steps. The E-step calculates the conditional expectation, and the M-step maximizes the updated likelihood function. Although the convergence of the EM algorithm could be slow, the general theory has shown that each iteration increases the likelihood and the MLEs are generally achieved (Dempster et al. 1977). The accuracy of haplotype frequency estimates are in general relatively good, except in the case of low frequency haplotypes (see e.g., Schipper et al. 1998, Fallin and Schork 2000, Tishkoff et al. 2000, Single et al. 2002). Large over and under estimates of particular HFs can occur even for common haplotypes, especially when the loci involved deviate significantly from HWP (Single et al. 2002). Estimating HFs for three or more loci and then collapsing over loci so as to generate two locus haplotypes can improve the accuracy of the estimation. The collapsing procedure is most beneficial when one of the loci in the two-locus haplotype of interest deviates significantly from HWP and the locus collapsed over is in linkage disequilibrium with the other loci (Single et al 2002).

figure.title: Performance of EM algorithm in recovering known haplotypes (see text for discussion)

sect2.para: The performance of the EM algorithm for the estimation of haplotypes in the HLA region is illustrated in These are results from a study reported in Single et al. (2002) where family data allowed haplotypes to be unambiguously inferred, so true and estimated haplotype frequencies could be compared. The graphs depict the performance of the EM algorithm in inferring two-locus haplotypes for selected pairs of sites. The circles represent true haplotype frequencies, and the lines represent estimated haplotype frequencies. Two-locus haplotypes for the DPB1 and A loci offer an example of how pairs of loci between which there is little LD allow only poor estimates of haplotype frequencies: notice the large discrepancies between true (circles) and inferred (lines) frequencies. In addition, note how for the DPB1-A haplotypes there are instances of missed haplotypes (true haplotypes not inferred - represented by circles with no lines) and incorrect haplotypes (inferred but not real - represented by lines with no circle). The locus pair DQB1-DRB1 exemplifies completely accurate inference. This results from the high LD values between these tightly linked loci. Finally, an intermediate scenario is exemplified by the inference of frequencies for the DQB1-B haplotype.

The performance of the EM algorithm also differs depending on the true frequency of the haplotypes being estimated. The table below compares the true and estimated haplotype sets using a measure that takes into account the frequency differences among observed and inferred haplotypes (the If measure, see Single et al. 2002). High values imply poor estimates (maximum being 1) and low values imply accurate estimates (minimum being 0). Notice that when haplotypes that are present as a single copy (column 1), the estimation is very inaccurate, but improves as the true frequency increases. The haplotypes present as 4 or more copies are estimated most accurately. This confirms the intuition that low frequency haplotypes are difficult to infer using the EM algorithm. A similar result was obtained by Tishkoff et al. (2000).

sect2.title: Testing for significance of linkage disequilibrium in a likelihood framework
sect2.para: Two approaches can be used to quantify and test linkage disequilibrium (LD). The first consists of using known haplotype frequencies to obtain LD values. Overall measures of LD, which account for deviations from free association among all pairs of alleles at two loci, can be used to generate test statistics that can be tested using parametric tests. For example, the overall measure of LD, Q (discussed in Hedrick, 1987) follows a chi-square distribution with (k-1)(l-1) degrees of freedom for datasets under linkage equilibrium (where k and l are the number of alleles at the first and second locus, respectively). However, if haplotypes are inferred from unphased genotype data this approach is limited in that the uncertainty inherent in the haplotype estimation is not accounted for when LD values are estimated and tested. The following likelihood-based approach circumvents this limitation.

Two likelihood values are defined: L_0 is the likelihood of observed genotypic data given the estimated haplotype set (this is the likelihood value obtained using the EM algorithm). L_1 is the likelihood of the observed data given haplotype frequencies expected under complete equilibrium (i.e. haplotype frequencies are given by the product of allele frequencies at each locus). The test-statistic is defined as:

The significance (p-value) of the observed test statistic can be obtained from a permutation test. The logic behind a permutation test for the significance of linkage disequilibrium is that under the null hypothesis of no disequilibrium any genotype at one site is going to occur with any genotype at another site with the frequency equal to the product of those genotype frequencies. Thus, by randomly permuting the observed genotypes at the separate sites among the individuals in the sample, the marginal allele frequencies (and genotype frequencies) are unaltered, but the new genotype combinations for the individuals in the sample are one realization under the null hypothesis. By generating many such permuted datasets and evaluating each dataset by whatever statistic is being used, one generates a distribution of the statistic under the null hypothesis. The statistic for the observed data can then be compared to the distribution and the significance is the fraction of the permuted datasets with a statistic greater than the observed. As stated above, the statistic we use is the likelihood ratio for the observed data with the estimated haplotype frequencies compared to with equilibrium haplotype frequencies.

An example is provided in , where the distribution of S for a sample of Filipino individuals for haplotypes involving the DQB1 and DPA1 loci. The observed value of S is indicated by an arrow, showing that the probability of obtaining a value of S as extreme as that observed is 0.001 under the null hypothesis (no association between loci). Thus we reject the null hypothesis.

sect2.title: Homozygosity test of neutrality
sect2.para: The neutral theory of evolution at a locus assumes that all alleles are selectively equivalent, that mutation is the source of new genetic variation, and that genetic drift results in loss of variation. Ewens (1972) developed a sampling theory that predicts the distribution of alleles at a locus drawn from a population at equilibrium under neutrality. Watterson (1978) developed a method, using a homozygosity measure, denoted by F, for the observed number of alleles and sample size, to compare a sample of allele frequencies to neutrality expectations. For a given number of observed alleles, a low value of the homozygosity measure F, compared to the neutrality expectation, corresponds to all alleles having similar frequencies. Some form of balancing selection is implied when the observed allele frequencies are more even than the neutrality expectation (Watterson 1978). A high value of F, compared to the neutrality expectation, corresponds to one allele predominating with the others at low frequencies. Directional selection is implicated in this case. Note that fit of a sample of allele frequencies to neutrality expectations does not mean that selection is not operating, but simply that one cannot reject the neutral model.

sect2.title: Methods
sect2.para: The observed frequency distribution of alleles in a population is compared to neutrality expectations under an infinite alleles model. The expected proportion of homozygotes under Hardy-Weinberg, i.e., the statistic F = sum(pi to 2) of Watterson (1978) for an observed number of alleles k (or amino acids at a site) and sample size n individuals (2n chromosomes), was compared with the distribution expected under the neutral model (Ewens 1972). Note that the Watterson homozygosity test of neutrality does not examine deviations from Hardy-Weinberg proportions, but utilizes the expected Hardy-Weinberg homozygosity as a measure of the distribution of allelic frequencies, for a given sample size (k) and observed number of alleles (2n). The expected values of F, and the variance and quantiles under the neutrality model can be found at http://allele5.biol.berkeley.edu/homozygosity/homozygosity.html (Salamon H, Nelson M, Thomson G). The exact test developed by Slatkin (1994, 1996), which calculates the probability of the observed configuration under neutrality, can also be implemented.
To allow comparison of homozygosity F statistics across populations with different numbers of alleles and sample sizes, the normalized deviate, FND, is considered (Salamon et al. 1999),

Under the neutral model, FND has mean zero and variance 1. If we assume that samples from different populations are statistically independent, the Central Limit Theorem predicts that the distribution of the mean of FND values across populations can be approximated by a standard normal distribution.

sect2.title: Application of Ewens-Watterson test of neutrality to HLA allele data
sect2.para: Allele frequencies within a population for serologically typed HLA class I A, B, and C and the class II DR locus, and for molecularly typed class II DRB1, DQA1, and DQB1, are often more even than expected under neutrality, suggesting that some form of balancing selection is operating on these genes (Hedrick and Thomson 1983, Klitz et al. 1986, 1992, Begovich et al. 1992). In contrast, the distribution of DPB1 alleles rarely differs significantly from neutrality expectations; usually there is a fairly common allele, which may differ between populations.

In both Salamon et al. (1999) and Valdes et al. (1999) where HLA class II data were analyzed, DQB1 showed striking evidence (in individual populations and overall) for balancing selection (allele frequencies more even than expected under the neutral model). DQA1 and DRB1 also showed significant evidence of balancing selection. Individual and overall population statistics for DPB1 were compatible with neutrality expectations in both studies. DPA1 allele and DPA1-DPB1 haplotype frequencies showed no evidence of deviation from neutrality expectations in the CEPH data (Moonsamy et al. 1997). The results for class II loci demonstrate that departure from neutrality is locus specific, despite the linkage disequilibrium in the region, which is particularly strong for DR-DQ.

The table below summarizes the findings of Valdes et al. (1999), illustrating (a) the large number of populations for which neutrality was rejected at certain loci; (b) the heterogeneity among loci with respect to deviation from neutrality. Notice than in all loci, except DPB1, the mean homozygosity across populations is lower than expected under neutrality.

In contrast to the allele level variation, at the amino acid level all 4 class II (DRB1, DQB1, DQA1, DPB1) loci showed evidence of balancing selection at many polymorphic codon sites, and consistently so across diverse populations. However, directional selection was seen for a few sites, and neutrality profiles were exhibited by other codons (Salamon et al. 1999, Valdes et al. 1999). Cases of amino acid variation showing balancing selection occurred at sites both within the highly polymorphic antigen recognition site (ARS) and outside it. Only for DRB1 was there evidence of more balancing selection for ARS sites compared to non-ARS sites. As the determination of DQ and DP ARS sites is based on theoretical models in lieu of the crystal structure, it is possible that many of the sites designated as non-ARS may actually be involved in antigen presentation. It is of particular interest in this context that two non-ARS sites identified as highly polymorphic and showing balancing selection (DQA1#47 and DQB1#26) have also been identified as amino acids involved in predisposition to type 1 diabetes (Valdes et al. 1997).
